Using cram_bandit_sim() with Contextual Bandit Policies

Source: vignettes/cram_bandit_helpers.Rmd
cram_bandit_helpers.Rmd

üéØ What is cram_bandit_sim()?

The function cram_bandit_sim() evaluates contextual bandit algorithms using the CRAM method. It is built on top of the contextual package, with several extensions for batch-aware evaluation and high-precision probability tracking.

üß© How it works

CRAM for contextual bandits relies on accurately estimating the action probabilities œÄt(Xt,at)\pi_t(X_t, a_t). These are essential for computing unbiased on-policy estimators:

VÃÇœÄ=1T‚àët=1Trt‚ãÖùüôat=œÄt(Xt)œÄt(Xt,at) \hat{V}_\pi = \frac{1}{T} \sum_{t=1}^T \frac{r_t \cdot \mathbb{1}_{a_t = \pi_t(X_t)}}{\pi_t(X_t, a_t)}

To do this, we:

  1. Use custom subclasses of contextual::Policy and contextual::Bandit
  2. Store and update model parameters (A, b, etc.)
  3. Reconstruct the probability that the selected arm was chosen

üß† Custom Bandit: ContextualLinearBandit

We extend the standard linear bandit to explicitly expose the underlying beta matrix used in reward generation. This allows us to compute the true expected rewards and compare against estimated values.

bandit <- ContextualLinearBandit$new(k = 3, d = 5)

üèóÔ∏è Batch-Aware Policies

To allow CRAM‚Äôs learning-evaluation cycles, we implement batch versions of common policies:

Policy Type Class Name
Epsilon-Greedy BatchContextualEpsilonGreedyPolicy
LinUCB BatchLinUCBDisjointPolicyEpsilon
Thompson Sampling BatchContextualLinTSPolicy

Each batch policy only updates its internal parameters every batch_size steps, enabling stable, evaluable policies.

üî¢ How Probabilities Are Computed

We use custom logic to reconstruct the selection probabilities œÄt(Xt,at)\pi_t(X_t, a_t) for each algorithm from its internal model state:

‚úÖ Epsilon-Greedy

With exploration probability Œµ, the probability of selecting a greedy arm is:

P(at|Xt)=(1‚àíœµ)‚ãÖ1#greedy arms+œµK P(a_t | X_t) = \left(1 - \epsilon\right) \cdot \frac{1}{\#\text{greedy arms}} + \frac{\epsilon}{K}

We detect which arms are greedy by computing Œ∏k=Ak‚àí1bk\theta_k = A_k^{-1} b_k and evaluating expected rewards.

get_proba_c_eps_greedy(eps, A_list, b_list, contexts, chosen_arms)

‚úÖ LinUCB Disjoint

LinUCB selects arms by adding an exploration bonus based on uncertainty:

P(at|Xt)=(1‚àíœµ)‚ãÖ1#best arms+œµK P(a_t | X_t) = \left(1 - \epsilon \right) \cdot \frac{1}{\#\text{best arms}} + \frac{\epsilon}{K}

This accounts for confidence intervals using Œºk+Œ±‚ãÖœÉk\mu_k + \alpha \cdot \sigma_k. CRAM tracks this precisely using:

get_proba_ucb_disjoint(alpha, eps, A_list, b_list, contexts, chosen_arms)

‚úÖ Thompson Sampling

This is more subtle: we integrate over the probability that the chosen arm outperforms all others given posterior uncertainty:

P(at|Xt)=‚Ñô[Œ∏atTXt>Œ∏kTXt‚àÄk‚â†at] P(a_t | X_t) = \mathbb{P}\left[\theta_{a_t}^T X_t > \theta_k^T X_t \quad \forall k \neq a_t\right]

We perform numerical integration over these multivariate Gaussians using:

get_proba_thompson(sigma, A_list, b_list, contexts, chosen_arms)

This is computationally expensive but precise.

üß™ Estimand Calculation

Once policies are reconstructed, we compute their true expected value using independent contexts and the known reward function:

compute_estimand(data_group, list_betas, policy, policy_name, batch_size, bandit)

This is essential to evaluate bias and coverage of the CRAM estimators.

üî• Optimizations

  • Probabilities are vectorized across timesteps and batches
  • We use Sherman-Morrison updates for fast matrix inverses
  • The function extract_2d_from_3d() performs efficient 3D slicing to isolate selected arm probabilities
  • Confidence intervals are calculated using asymptotic variance estimates

üì¶ Example 

# Set up bandit and policy
bandit <- ContextualLinearBandit$new(k = 3, d = 5)
policy <- BatchLinUCBDisjointPolicyEpsilon$new(alpha = 1.0, epsilon = 0.1, batch_size = 10)

# Run CRAM Bandit simulation
results <- cram_bandit_sim(
  horizon = 100,
  simulations = 5,
  bandit = bandit,
  policy = policy,
  alpha = 0.05
)

head(results)

üìö See Also

  • contextual: Bandit simulation framework
  • cram_bandit() ‚Äî to compute value/CI for one policy trajectory
  • compute_probas() ‚Äî probability matrix reconstruction engine
